questiontext.text:
Example

Suppose that the relationship between variables \(x\) and \(y\) is given by \(y = ab^x\) where \(a\) and \(b\) are positive constants. An experiment to test that the data did follow this relationship was plotted on a log-scaled graph of \(x\) against \(Y = \ln(y)\). Given that the points \((0,3)\) and \((7,5)\) lie on the line in the graph find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

Solution

Since we are old that \(x\) is plotted against \(Y= \ln(y)\) we know that the data follow a straight line. Therefore we need to obtain a straight line equation from \(y = ab^x\). So taking logs as before and using the log laws to simplify we obtain. \[ \begin{align*} \ln(y) &= \ln(ab^x) \\ &= \ln(a) + x\ln(b) \\ &= Y = (\ln(b))x + \ln(a). \end{align*} \] Since this is now an equation of a straight line we need to find the \(y\)-intercept and the gradient. Happily we are told that \((0,3)\) lies on the line so the y-intercept is \(3\). therefore \(ln(a) = 3\) and thus \(a = e^3\).

We can find the gradient as follows \[ \ln(b) = \frac{5-3}{7-0} = 2/7. \] Hence, b = e^{2/7} and the equation of the line is \(Y = e^{\frac{2}{7}}x + e^{3}\).
